com.pholser.lambspec

Class Lambspec

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.pholser.lambspec.Lambspec

  • public class Lambspec
extends Object
    Sugar methods/fields for creating expectations in the form of Predicates.

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      static Predicate<Object> alwaysFalse
      Predicate that answers false no matter its argument.
      static Predicate<Object> alwaysTrue
      Predicate that answers true no matter its argument.

    • Method Detail

      • satisfy

        public static <S> Predicate<S> satisfy(Predicate<S> p)

        When the argument to Subject.to(Predicate) is a lambda expression or named in a way that doesn't read fluently, this method can help.

        For example:

        subject("foo").must(satisfy(s -> s.length() == 3));
        Type Parameters:
        S - the type of the argument to the predicate
        Parameters:
        p - a predicate
        Returns:
        p

      • satisfyAny

        @SafeVarargs
public static <S> Predicate<S> satisfyAny(Predicate<S> first,
                                                       Predicate<? super S>... rest)

        Creates a disjunction predicate from many other predicates.

        This method is sugar for chained calls to Predicate.or(Predicate).

        For example:

        subject("foo").must(satisfyAny(s -> s.length() == 3, s -> s.startsWith("x"));
        Type Parameters:
        S - a constraint on the type of the arguments to the predicates
        Parameters:
        first - a predicate
        rest - zero or more predicates
        Returns:
        a predicate that is the disjunction of the given predicates

      • satisfyAll

        @SafeVarargs
public static <S> Predicate<S> satisfyAll(Predicate<S> first,
                                                       Predicate<? super S>... rest)

        Creates a conjunction predicate from many other predicates.

        This method is sugar for chained calls to Predicate.and(Predicate).

        For example:

        subject("foo").must(satisfyAll(s -> s.length() == 3, s -> s.startsWith("f"));
        Type Parameters:
        S - a constraint on the type of the arguments to the predicates
        Parameters:
        first - a predicate
        rest - zero or more predicates
        Returns:
        a predicate that is the conjunction of the given predicates

      • haveAnItemSatisfying

        public static <S> Predicate<Iterable<S>> haveAnItemSatisfying(Predicate<? super S> p)
        Creates a predicate that decides whether an element of its Iterable argument satisfies the given predicate.
        Type Parameters:
        S - a constraint on the type of the elements of the sequence
        Parameters:
        p - the predicate to apply to elements of a sequence
        Returns:
        a predicate that tests elements of the sequence against the given predicate

      • have

        public static <S> Predicate<Iterable<S>> have(S item)
        Creates a predicate that decides whether a given item is in the given sequence.
        Type Parameters:
        S - the type of the item
        Parameters:
        item - the item to look for in the sequence
        Returns:
        a predicate that tests whether the given item is in a sequence

      • be

        public static <S> Predicate<S> be(S other)

        Creates a predicate that decides whether a given item is equal to another.

        This is sugar for Predicate.isEqual(Object), and reads better than it as an argument to Subject.to(Predicate).

        Type Parameters:
        S - the type of the item
        Parameters:
        other - an item to compare to another
        Returns:
        a predicate that tests whether the given item equals another

      • not

        public static <S> Predicate<S> not(Predicate<S> p)

        Creates a predicate that is the negation of the given predicate.

        This method is sugar for Predicate.negate().

        Type Parameters:
        S - the type of the argument to the predicate
        Parameters:
        p - a predicate
        Returns:
        the negation of the given predicate
